bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, November 22, 1875

div1.p: Reed describes athletic events and a tournament. He comments on jealousy.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, November 22, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Novr 22th 75

div1.p:
Sunday
passed and gone, the time for
writing my Monday's letter again
arrives. What shall I write
on this most beautiful & bright
morning? Shall I tell my lit-
tle girl of the athletic sports
that I have taken part in during
the past week? Such as box
ing, daily; with a glove, on
each hand, larger than my
own head: or jumping over
a string, held a wonderful
height above the ground; or swinging clubs
of fabulous weight about my head; or ri-
ding horses of prodigious strength & speed?
These & many more, “mirabile diet” have oc-
cupied my moments; and this morning, I be-
gin to feel the effects. The latter displayed
in a very strange manner- such as an in-
ability to rise up quickly, or to walk fast,
on account of various excruciating aches
that rack my “body physical.” This is not
all, for we are going to have a tour-
nament this week: a real, sure-enough
tournament- on horse-back- with rings
suspended from a bar, & spears with
which to bear of these rings; but alas!--
we have no Queen, upon whose fair brow
the victor might place the crown! This is
a sad deficiency, & but for our innate
love of athletic exercise, our tournament
would “go by the board”.

Would you believe, after all I've told you, that
I've not been happy, for several days past?
As true as you live- Although, I said in my
last letter, that I had nothing
to say concerning your corres-
pondence with Mr Joynes (I don't
know that I spell his name right
or not, yet but you will understand,)
of Baltimore, Yet I have thought
over the matter a good deal
since I wrote. In fact, it has
been absent from my mind,
but for a few moments at
a time. I've tried to shake
it off, but the thought clings as
tenaciously as ever. Call it
jealousy, if you like. It may be,
and probably is. Although I
once imagined that I would
never be jealous, & although
it is a strange confession for
a gentleman to make to a lady,
yet I find that the demands
of truth require it. Call me
silly, if you please. But I'm only a boy, &
have not yet put aside silly thoughts and
feelings. Older heads than mine have ached and
older hearts have bled. Ive have not made
objection to your correspondence, nor shall I
do. Neither shall I tell you my own opinion.
You would say it was a predjudiced one &
as such would put it aside. Yet when I see
a gentleman asking a lady to correspond with him-
a lady whom he knows to be engaged- I am
sensible enough to know that he intends to
ask the lady's hand. And then when I think
that he is a “high-toned & cultivated” gentleman;
that he has a home in a beautiful City of
the “Sunny South”; is surrounded by friends;
is indirectly related to this lady; that he would
have all the influence that could be possibly
brought to bear upon a young heart to yield it-
self to his keeping; and then turning to myself,
think of my utter unworthiness; my lack of ed-
ucation; my uninviting disposition; the life that
is before me; my lack of ambition; my failures
in the past; my prospects for the Future; ah!
when, again & again, I have revolved these
thoughts in my mind (and they will not begone)
I begin to see the bright vision, that has cheered
me, for many months past, fade into dreariness & dark-
ness, and I can almost see the beautiful idol
that, I have looked upon & loved, slying, at my feet,
shattered into a thousand fragments! Oh! do not
think that I do not mean what I say. There's no Irony
in this! Is the picture dark? Who can tell the va-
rious changing scenes of a young girl's heart?
The whence & the wherefore? “Oh! this morn I put
my hand in thine & vow that thee, alone I love”!
A day later, and the very echo of those words
startles her! She fain would not own them!
“Young gentlemen are not one whit more
stable,” you say, & I will not deny it. Let a gen-
tleman or lady, I care not who they may be, begin to
share their time & attention with another, and from
that moment, the old love commences to grow dim!
The Present governs the man, & the woman too! And
there is no escape. In conclusion, my little darling,
let me say that if your new correspondent should
develop into a near friend & friendship into
a holier feeling, do not let me stand in the
way of your happiness. I would love you still.
div1.closer:
Believe me, as ever, your
fond & devoted Walter.
